content: The "Foreign Medical School Accountability Fairness Act of 2017" aims to establish consistent eligibility requirements for foreign medical schools to increase accountability and protect American students and taxpayer dollars. The "Foreign Medical School Accountability Fairness Act of 2017" aims to establish consistent eligibility requirements for foreign medical schools to increase accountability and protect American students and taxpayer dollars. Three for-profit Caribbean medical schools receive the majority of Federal funding under title IV of the Higher Education Act, despite being exempt from meeting the same eligibility requirements as other foreign medical schools. The attrition rate at Caribbean medical schools can reach 30 percent, much higher than the 3.4 percent average at US medical schools. Foreign trained graduates have a lower residency match rate of 54 percent compared to 94 percent for US graduates. In 2014, US medical schools had an average attrition rate of 3.4%, while for-profit Caribbean medical schools can reach 30%. In 2016, foreign trained graduates had a residency match rate of 54%, compared to 94% for US graduates. Students at for-profit medical schools outside the US and Canada accumulate more debt than those in the US. SEC. 4. REPEAL GRANDFATHER PROVISIONS. Section 102(a)(2) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require that a graduate medical school located outside the United States must have at least 60 percent of enrolled students and graduates who were not described in a specific section in the previous year. Additionally, at least 75 percent of students or graduates must be nationals of the United States or Canada. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require that a graduate medical school outside the US must have a majority of students who were not described in a specific section in the previous year. Additionally, a high percentage of students or graduates must be US or Canadian nationals to qualify for participation in loan programs under part D of title IV. The authority of a foreign medical school to participate in loan programs under title IV will expire on July 1 after the enactment of the Foreign Medical School Accountability Fairness Act of 2017. If a graduate medical school loses eligibility for loan programs under the Higher Education Act, enrolled students can still receive loans until they withdraw, complete their program, or the fourth June 30 after the loss of eligibility.
